author: ReflectAA
body:
Citing false documents is also not against the law by itself though. A plaintiff would have to prove they *created* the false documents, which is difficult.

I think you don’t realize just how often this stuff happens. At least a couple times a year I see a stock on my portfolio or watchlist affected by something like this. The most memorable examples are AMD and ENPH

author: CapitalC5
body:
Simple, you don't. Belief in a company or industry can change and you can never be 100% certain for 10 or even 5 years. But you're pretty sure it will be great for a decent time and if something comes up, just act to it. 

I also believed ENPH was going to be the biggest player in solar energy, but I've sold immediately when there were fraud accusations, even if it turns out they are not grounded.

Look at Buffett being a big fan of airlines, well not anymore. He said the industry has changed too much. Such things can happen all the time because of certain events, crisis, regulations, etc.

author: ADKTrader1976
body: Although I do agree about nuclear energy is much more of an efficient way to produce energy for the masses, you are over looking a few issues with your bull run theory.  Nuclear is not something the United States, Japan, UK, Germany, or the rest of the 1st world countries want to go because of the waste and environmental impact.  China and India are the two majors that would need to commit to nuclear, and if they do, dollars to doughnuts they are not gonna use mines located in the US.  Another thing to consider, is that if people start to move out of the cities and people dense areas to more sparsely populated areas what is gonna prevent them to stay complete off the grid if it's possible with today's tech.  The pitifalls of the past in using renewable energy as the primary source to power a home has always been the conversion and storage part of the equation,  not the acquisition of it.   On the inverter side, companies like SEDG and ENPH have held onto their gains and continue to show robust sales in both the US and Europe.  Tesla's power wall has been gaining momentum and is leading the way in batteries.  Tesla is not just a car company, it's a renewable energy infrastructure play that in years to come will drive the new IoT in the future.  Add Musk's satellite internet drive and there is broad brush stroke of the next market cycle.

author: _TheNorseman_
body:
Sure thing. 

Just play it safe. I haven’t been investing long myself (close to 2 years) and my knowledge is still just a drop in the bucket. I started off like you, just jumping right in while investing in things I was 100% sure at the time would be wins. A few got me 20% gains... but I had far more that were -40% and as terrible as -70%. My first year resulted in losing far more than I gained, and therefore a net loss. Thankfully I only had a small amount of money in the game, so my losses weren’t something that put me in a financial crisis. That’s when I realized I need to focus more on “what will net me the highest chance of a positive return by the time I retire?” And for me the answer is ETFs, although I do have a few individual stocks (ENPH, AMD, DAL) but I only invested in them what I was comfortable with losing (and only invested in DAL when the pandemic hit and they had a massive dip), and not swinging for the fences. 

Money in general is very important... a comfortable retirement should be the end goal, though... so don’t rush it.

author: lloydgross24
body:
nah don't mess with penny stocks.

Options are the way in the volatility. They are risky for sure but you can do quite well if you are smart about it. And generally a bit more predictable based on patterns and valuations. 

ENPH is a great example. Every time there is a dip, you can buy towards the bottom and it'll recover within a week. It keeps a trading range. AMD is another one. You can find a ton of stocks that bounce between trading ranges. 

But you can also play them off unusual activity or around before expected news. 

AZN had around a 6% day yesterday. My options went up 176% since I got in a few days earlier before the IV spike. 

Got be careful with them tho and only trade with a certain position of your portfolio. I try to keep 10% or lower. Also make sure you fully understand them and know what you are doing. But most people stay away because they don't understand them... Even Warren Buffett uses options at times.
ENPH begs to differ

author: drnick5
body:
I've mentioned this company a few times whenever solar is brought up. Don't look at the panels, look at the inverter companies. Of which its basically a duopoly of ENPH and SEDG. Every solar array needs an inverter, regardless of which brand panels (or solar roof) you use. If I remember correctly Solarege inverters are 99% efficient, and Enphase is only 97% with its microinverters. 

Personally, my solar array has a Solaredge inverter, and its been great so far.

author: lick_my_eye
body:
this is a nice list!  I’m really curious about NKLA, though.  I’ve watched a lot of interviews with Milton and other presentations about the business model for this company.  I still am scratching my head on how this has a $15B market cap, zero sales and a handful of prototypes.  Plus a constantly evolving business model.  Every day, I am less and less impressed with the leadership at Nikola.  I’ve been wrong many times about stocks, so who knows, but with NKLA there appear to be many many red flags.

Full disclosure, I am invested in tesla, but I’m always interested in renewable stocks and also own ENPH, NEE, BEP, NIO.  I also own hydrogen stocks like BLDP and PLUG because it seems like there is a big push toward hydrogen globally.

I haven’t had a chance to look into SHLL, yet, but it sounds like they already EV trucks?

author: Malamonga1
body: Good luck finding another ENPH again. ENPH was truly a unicorn penny stock with a product that is actually stellar (for residential purposes dare I say slightly better than SolarEdge). CLSK on the other hand, seems to be focusing on real time energy trading and optimization applications, which is a bit futuristic in my opinion. We won't have a strong need for that until much heavier renewable penetration, possibly 2030 (for California) or later (for other states in the East coast). Even in CA there is not a strong need for that yet. Academics at universities are just now starting to pay attention to the data analytics aspect of renewable.

author: TheTigersAreNotReal
body:
GLW: Glass manufacturer that is used in vials, phones, TVs, and other medical/commercial appliances. They have a contract to produce vials for Pfizer, and received a grant from the government to ensure that they will be able to produce enough vials for the future vaccine. Had their price target upgraded to $33 by Citigroup, currently oversold at $25.75

Don’t know when this thing is gonna moon again, but I hope it’s soon. Probably needs to announce another biomed contract to turn more heads. White knuckling these calls hoping the market realizes its value soon

author: math1024
body:
The main difference between 5G and the previous roll outs is just a lot more fiber and small cell antennas. I think the best 5G plays would be fiber companies like GLW, COMM, and OCC.

There's also been [legislation](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_13858) promoting onshoring so you might want to focus on american manufacturers.
